ground_truth: She heads back inside, studying the unopened letter, and goes to knock on the door of Mr. Bennet's study. She goes inside and hands over the letter. Mr. Bennet leaves the letter on the desk until the housekeeper has left. The housekeeper now makes her way out into the garden to take down the washing. Jane and Lizzie are picking fruit. Lizzie puts down her basket and rushes off, quickly followed by Jane. The two girls hurry around the outside of the house, then across the wide expanse of lawn, looking for their father. They spot him, arms behind his back, strolling pensively into the shade of the trees. They rush over to him. Lizzie sits down with the letter. Lizzie stands up, looking perturbed. Later, Lizzie's in Jane's bedroom in her nightgown. Jane sits by the fire, drying her hair. Lizzie sits sadly on the stool at the foot of Jane's bed. Mr. Darcy's expression is one of determined constancy. A lady's hand at work on a delicate piece of floral embroidery. Lizzie stands and leaves. With a heavy heart, Lizzie makes her way over to her father's study. She pauses to watch him through the doorway and slowly goes inside. He turns round and takes her hand. Two of them listen to Mrs. Bennet's hysterical chatter. Lizzie does so. A building fronted by magnificent pillared portico. An open-topped carriage pulls up, drawn by two white horses. Lydia gets out, dressed in a simple, empire line wedding dress and bonnet, and carrying a bunch of flowers. The Gardiners are with her. Beaming, she takes Mr. Gardiner's hand and heads up the steps. Inside, Mr. Wickham stands up, ready to receive his bride. Mr. Darcy appears beside him, his face taut with anger. Lydia walks down the aisle, grinning, and takes her place beside Mr. Wickham at the altar. The vicar comes to stand before them. An open-topped carriage trundles down the long driveway at Longbourn. Mr. and Mrs. Wickham are sitting in the back. The Bennet family come out to greet them. Mrs. Bennet waving a white handkerchief excitedly above her head. Mrs. Bennet takes her husband's arm and leads the way. Jane makes to follow them. Jane and Lizzie exchange glances, then head inside, followed by Mary and Kitty. Later, the girls are out walking. Mr. Wickham is showing off his riding skills nearby. Wickham canters past them and makes his horse jump over a log. Wickham rides past them again, and Lydia grins cheekily at her sisters. Lizzie looks thoughtful. Mr. Gardiner proffers his hand, and the deal is done. Wickham finds Lizzie reading the letter. She looks away, embarrassed. They walk together in the gardens of Longbourn.

test_cases.description: She directs back indoors, examining the unopened note, and proceeds to knock on the portal of Mr. Bennet's study. She enters and delivers the note. Mr. Bennet places the note on the table until the housekeeper has departed. The housekeeper now makes her path out into the garden to take down the laundry. Jane and Lizzie are gathering fruit. Lizzie sets down her basket and dashes off, swiftly followed by Jane. The two maidens hurry around the exterior of the residence, then across the broad stretch of lawn, searching for their father. They identify him, arms behind his back, ambling thoughtfully into the shade of the trees. They dash over to him. Lizzie sits down with the note. Lizzie stands up, appearing perturbed. Lydia alights, dressed in a simple, empire line bridal dress and bonnet, and bearing a bouquet of flowers. The Gardiners are with her. Beaming, she takes Mr. Gardiner's hand and directs up the steps. Inside, Mr. Wickham rises, prepared to receive his bride. Mr. Darcy appears beside him, his visage taut with ire. Lydia walks down the aisle, grinning, and takes her position beside Mr. Wickham at the altar. The vicar comes to stand before them. Mrs. Bennet waving a white handkerchief excitedly above her head. Mrs. Bennet takes her husband's arm and leads the path. Jane makes to follow them. Jane follows, exchanging glances with Lizzie, then heads inside with Mary and Kitty. Later, the girls walk outside. Mr. Wickham shows off his riding skills nearby, cantering past and jumping a log. Lydia grins cheekily at her sisters. Lizzie looks thoughtful. Mr. Gardiner offers his hand, sealing the deal. Wickham finds Lizzie reading the letter; she looks away, embarrassed. They walk together in Longbourn's gardens.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: She makes her way back inside the house, her eyes intently studying the unopened letter in her hand, and proceeds to knock gently on the door of Mr. Bennet's study. Upon entering, she hands over the letter to him. Mr. Bennet places the letter on his desk, choosing to leave it there until the housekeeper has departed. The housekeeper, having completed her task, now heads out into the garden to take down the washing that has been hanging to dry. Meanwhile, Jane and Lizzie are busy picking fruit. Lizzie sets her basket down and quickly rushes off, with Jane following closely behind her. The two sisters hurry around the exterior of the house and then dash across the wide expanse of the lawn, eagerly searching for their father. They soon spot him, his arms clasped behind his back, as he strolls pensively into the cool shade of the trees. They rush over to join him. Lizzie sits down with the letter in hand. She then stands up, looking visibly perturbed. Later, Lizzie finds herself in Jane's bedroom, dressed in her nightgown. Jane is seated by the fire, drying her hair. Lizzie sits sadly on the small stool at the foot of Jane's bed. Mr. Darcy's expression is one of unwavering determination. A lady's hand is seen skillfully working on a delicate piece of floral embroidery. Lizzie stands and leaves the room. With a heavy heart, she makes her way over to her father's study once more. She pauses to watch him through the doorway before slowly stepping inside. He turns around and takes her hand gently. The two of them listen to Mrs. Bennet's hysterical chatter. Lizzie complies. A grand building is fronted by a magnificent pillared portico. An open-topped carriage arrives, drawn by two elegant white horses. Lydia steps out, dressed in a simple, empire line wedding dress and bonnet, carrying a lovely bunch of flowers. The Gardiners accompany her. Beaming with joy, she takes Mr. Gardiner's hand and heads up the steps. Inside, Mr. Wickham stands up, ready to receive his bride. Mr. Darcy appears beside him, his face taut with anger. Lydia walks down the aisle, grinning broadly, and takes her place beside Mr. Wickham at the altar. The vicar comes to stand before them, ready to officiate. An open-topped carriage trundles down the long driveway at Longbourn. Mr. and Mrs. Wickham are seated in the back. The Bennet family comes out to greet them, with Mrs. Bennet waving a white handkerchief excitedly above her head. Mrs. Bennet takes her husband's arm and leads the way. Jane prepares to follow them. Jane and Lizzie exchange knowing glances, then head inside, followed by Mary and Kitty. Later, the girls are out walking together. Mr. Wickham is nearby, showing off his riding skills. Wickham canters past them and makes his horse jump gracefully over a log. Wickham rides past them once more, and Lydia grins cheekily at her sisters. Lizzie appears thoughtful. Mr. Gardiner offers his hand, and the deal is sealed. Wickham finds Lizzie reading the letter. She looks away, feeling embarrassed. They walk together in the beautiful gardens of Longbourn.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: She slowly makes her way back into the cozy confines of the house, her eyes intensely focused on the unopened letter she holds delicately in her hand. She proceeds to knock gently on the solid wood door of Mr. Bennet's quiet study. Upon entering the room, she gracefully hands the letter over to him. Mr. Bennet then places the letter on his desk, deciding to leave it untouched until the housekeeper has finished her duties and has left the room. The housekeeper, having completed her assigned tasks, now steps out into the garden to take down the washing that has been hanging up to dry in the sun. Meanwhile, Jane and Lizzie are occupied with the task of picking ripe fruit from the trees. Lizzie sets her basket down and suddenly rushes off, with Jane following close behind her, not missing a beat. The two sisters hurry excitedly around the exterior of the house and then dash across the expansive, lush lawn, eagerly searching for their father in the grounds. They soon spot him, his arms clasped thoughtfully behind his back, as he leisurely strolls into the cool, inviting shade of the trees. They rush over enthusiastically to join him. Lizzie sits down with the letter clutched in her hand, and after a moment, stands up, looking notably perturbed. Later that evening, Lizzie finds herself in the comfort of Jane's warmly lit bedroom, dressed in her simple nightgown. Jane is seated calmly by the fire, carefully drying her hair. Lizzie sits sadly on the small wooden stool at the foot of Jane's bed. Mr. Darcy's expression is fixed in one of unwavering determination. A lady's hand is shown skillfully working on a delicate piece of floral embroidery. Lizzie stands up and exits the room. With a heavy heart and deep sigh, she makes her way once more to her father's study. She pauses briefly, watching him through the doorway before slowly stepping inside. He turns around to face her and gently takes her hand in his. Together, they listen to Mrs. Bennet's hysterical chatter from the other room. Lizzie complies silently. A grand building stands prominently, fronted by a magnificent pillared portico. An elegant open-topped carriage arrives, drawn by two strikingly beautiful white horses. Lydia steps out, wearing a simple yet graceful, empire line wedding dress and bonnet, and she holds a lovely bouquet of fresh flowers. The Gardiners accompany her closely. Beaming with uncontainable joy, she takes Mr. Gardiner's hand and heads confidently up the steps. Inside, Mr. Wickham stands up, ready and waiting to receive his bride. Mr. Darcy appears beside him, his face taut with visible anger. Lydia walks down the aisle, grinning broadly, and takes her place beside Mr. Wickham at the altar. The vicar comes to stand before them, fully prepared to officiate the ceremony. An open-topped carriage trundles steadily down the long, winding driveway at Longbourn. Mr. and Mrs. Wickham are comfortably seated in the back. The entire Bennet family comes out to greet them, with Mrs. Bennet waving a white handkerchief excitedly above her head. Mrs. Bennet eagerly takes her husband's arm and leads the way. Jane prepares herself to follow them. Jane and Lizzie exchange knowing glances, then head inside, followed closely by Mary and Kitty. Later, the girls are out walking together along the path. Mr. Wickham is nearby, proudly showing off his impressive riding skills. Wickham canters past them and confidently makes his horse jump gracefully over a log. Wickham rides past them once more, and Lydia grins cheekily at her sisters. Lizzie appears lost in thought. Mr. Gardiner offers his hand, sealing the deal. Wickham finds Lizzie quietly reading the letter. She looks away, feeling a flush of embarrassment. Together, they walk along the picturesque paths in the beautiful gardens of Longbourn.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: She steps back inside, her eyes fixed on the unopened letter in her hand, and makes her way to Mr. Bennet's study, where she gently knocks on the door. Upon entering, she approaches Mr. Bennet and hands him the letter. Mr. Bennet places the letter on his desk, choosing to leave it untouched until the housekeeper has exited the room. The housekeeper then proceeds to the garden, her task being to take down the washing. Meanwhile, Jane and Lizzie are engaged in picking fruit. Lizzie sets her basket down and suddenly dashes off, with Jane quickly following her lead. The two sisters hurry around the exterior of the house and then sprint across the wide stretch of lawn, their eyes scanning for their father. They soon spot him, his arms clasped behind his back, as he strolls thoughtfully into the shade provided by the trees. They rush over to him, and Lizzie sits down with the letter in hand. After a moment, Lizzie stands up, her expression troubled. Later, Lizzie finds herself in Jane's bedroom, dressed in her nightgown, while Jane sits by the fire, drying her hair. Lizzie, looking forlorn, takes a seat on the stool at the foot of Jane's bed. Mr. Darcy's face is set with a look of determined constancy, while a lady's hand is busy working on a delicate piece of floral embroidery. Lizzie rises and departs, her heart heavy, as she makes her way to her father's study. She pauses to observe him through the doorway before slowly stepping inside. He turns to face her and takes her hand. Together, they listen to Mrs. Bennet's hysterical chatter, and Lizzie complies. A building with a grand pillared portico stands before them as an open-topped carriage, drawn by two white horses, pulls up. Lydia steps out, adorned in a simple empire line wedding dress and bonnet, clutching a bouquet of flowers. Accompanied by the Gardiners, she beams as she takes Mr. Gardiner's hand and ascends the steps. Inside, Mr. Wickham stands, poised to receive his bride, while Mr. Darcy appears beside him, his face taut with anger. Lydia, grinning, walks down the aisle and takes her place beside Mr. Wickham at the altar as the vicar steps forward to stand before them. An open-topped carriage makes its way down the long driveway at Longbourn, with Mr. and Mrs. Wickham seated in the back. The Bennet family emerges to greet them, with Mrs. Bennet waving a white handkerchief excitedly above her head. Mrs. Bennet takes her husband's arm and leads the way, prompting Jane to follow. Jane and Lizzie exchange glances before heading inside, with Mary and Kitty trailing behind. Later, the girls are out for a walk, and Mr. Wickham is nearby, showing off his riding skills. Wickham canters past them, making his horse leap over a log, and as he rides past again, Lydia grins cheekily at her sisters, while Lizzie appears deep in thought. Mr. Gardiner extends his hand, sealing the deal. Wickham finds Lizzie absorbed in reading the letter, and she looks away, feeling embarrassed. Together, they walk through the gardens of Longbourn.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: She returns inside with the unopened letter and knocks on Mr. Bennet's study door, handing it to him. After she leaves, Mr. Bennet sets the letter aside. The housekeeper heads to the garden to take down the washing, while Jane and Lizzie pick fruit. Lizzie quickly sets down her basket and rushes off with Jane, searching for their father. They find him strolling pensively under the trees and hurry over. Lizzie sits with the letter, then stands, looking perturbed. Later, in Jane's bedroom, Lizzie sits sadly at the foot of the bed while Jane dries her hair by the fire. Mr. Darcy's expression is one of determined constancy as a lady works on floral embroidery. Lizzie leaves with a heavy heart and goes to her father's study, pausing to watch him before entering. He turns and takes her hand as they listen to Mrs. Bennet's chatter. A carriage arrives at a building with a pillared portico. Lydia, in a simple wedding dress, exits with the Gardiners, takes Mr. Gardiner's hand, and heads inside. Mr. Wickham stands ready at the altar, with Mr. Darcy beside him, looking angry. Lydia grins as she joins Wickham, and the vicar stands before them. The newlyweds ride away in a carriage as the Bennet family greets them, with Mrs. Bennet excitedly waving a handkerchief. She takes her husband's arm, leading the way, followed by Jane, Lizzie, Mary, and Kitty. Later, the girls walk while Mr. Wickham shows off his riding skills, making his horse jump over a log. Lydia grins at her sisters as Wickham rides past again, while Lizzie looks thoughtful. Mr. Gardiner offers his hand, sealing a deal. Wickham finds Lizzie reading the letter, and they walk together in Longbourn's gardens, with Lizzie looking away, embarrassed.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: She heads back inside, studying the unopened letter with a curiosity that belied its plain appearance, and goes to knock on the door of Mr. Bennet's study, a room known for its shelves of dusty tomes and the scent of leather-bound volumes. She goes inside and hands over the letter. Mr. Bennet, known for his fondness for solitude and contemplation, leaves the letter on the desk until the housekeeper has left. The housekeeper now makes her way out into the garden, an area lined with rose bushes and lavender, to take down the washing drying in the gentle afternoon breeze. Jane and Lizzie are picking fruit, gathering ripe apples from the orchard that borders the estate. Lizzie puts down her basket and rushes off, quickly followed by Jane. The two girls hurry around the outside of the house, a Georgian manor reflective of its time with grand windows and stone facade, then across the wide expanse of lawn where summer picnics were often held, looking for their father. They spot him, arms behind his back, strolling pensively into the shade of the trees, where a family of sparrows flits from branch to branch. They rush over to him. Lizzie sits down with the letter, its seal still unbroken. Lizzie stands up, looking perturbed, her brow furrowed with worry. Later, Lizzie's in Jane's bedroom in her nightgown, a gift from her late grandmother. Jane sits by the fire, drying her hair, which hangs in loose curls. Lizzie sits sadly on the stool at the foot of Jane's bed, upholstered in a floral fabric that matched the curtains. Mr. Darcy's expression is one of determined constancy, a man of few words but strong convictions. A lady's hand at work on a delicate piece of floral embroidery, a common pastime in their social circle. Lizzie stands and leaves. With a heavy heart, Lizzie makes her way over to her father's study, a place of solace for her. She pauses to watch him through the doorway and slowly goes inside. He turns round and takes her hand, his touch reassuring. Two of them listen to Mrs. Bennet's hysterical chatter, a frequent occurrence in the household. Lizzie does so. A building fronted by a magnificent pillared portico, reminiscent of the great houses of the aristocracy. An open-topped carriage pulls up, drawn by two white horses, their coats gleaming in the sun. Lydia gets out, dressed in a simple, empire line wedding dress and bonnet, the height of fashion, and carrying a bunch of flowers gathered from the local meadow. The Gardiners are with her, their presence a comforting support. Beaming, she takes Mr. Gardiner's hand and heads up the steps. Inside, Mr. Wickham stands up, ready to receive his bride, his demeanor charming though not entirely trustworthy. Mr. Darcy appears beside him, his face taut with anger at the turn of events. Lydia walks down the aisle, grinning, and takes her place beside Mr. Wickham at the altar, the candles flickering softly. The vicar, an old family friend, comes to stand before them. An open-topped carriage trundles down the long driveway at Longbourn, wheels crunching over the gravel. Mr. and Mrs. Wickham are sitting in the back, their expressions a mix of triumph and anticipation. The Bennet family come out to greet them, emotions ranging from amusement to exasperation. Mrs. Bennet waving a white handkerchief excitedly above her head, her pride in her married daughter evident. Mrs. Bennet takes her husband's arm and leads the way. Jane makes to follow them. Jane and Lizzie exchange glances, then head inside, followed by Mary and Kitty, both quietly observing the spectacle. Later, the girls are out walking along a path lined with wildflowers. Mr. Wickham is showing off his riding skills nearby, as he often would to impress those around. Wickham canters past them and makes his horse jump over a log, demonstrating agility and confidence. Wickham rides past them again, and Lydia grins cheekily at her sisters, her excitement undiminished by the day's events. Lizzie looks thoughtful, her mind a whirl of concerns and reflections. Mr. Gardiner proffers his hand, and the deal is done, settling matters with a firm handshake. Wickham finds Lizzie reading the letter, her face a mask of concentration. She looks away, embarrassed at the intrusion. They walk together in the gardens of Longbourn, the air filled with the scent of roses and the sound of distant birdsong.

Mr. Burns's gesture is one of amused surprise. A man's foot at work on a delicate piece of wooden sculpture. Emma lies and dances. With a joyful grin, Emma sprints her route under to her mother's attic. He lunges to ignore her through the wall and swiftly dances outside. She frowns backward and releases his hat. Three of them ignore Mr. Smith's joyful silence. Emma does not. A doghouse decorated by hideous painted fountain. An empty boat stalls out, pushed by ten black dolphins. Robert jumps in, wearing an elaborate, Victorian-era crown and cape, and playing a bouquet of guitars. The Parkers are without him. Frowning, he loses Mrs. Parker's hat and sprints down the puddles. Outside, Mrs. Green collapses down, waiting to confuse her apprentice. Mr. Burns watches without him, her hair full with joy. Robert dances across the stage, singing, and loses his mind without Mrs. Green in the kitchen. The chef ceases to sleep above them. A closed boat crawls up the short stairway to the attic. Robert and Mary Green are standing in the front. The Smith family go in to ignore them. Mr. Smith tossing an old pair of shoes lazily under her feet. Mr. Smith releases his daughter's leg and follows the stairs. Emma dances to follow him. Emma and Susan swap manuscripting, then jump outside, chased by Alice and Nancy. Earlier, the dogs are inside reading. Mrs. Green is hiding off her swimming techniques faraway. Green swims next to them and makes her dog play under a leaf. Green gallops up them quietly, and Robert frowns sadly at his cousins. Emma feels relieved. Mrs. Parker refuses their foot, and the plan is shattered. Green misses Emma watching the suitcase. He smiles inwardly, fascinated. They sleep separately above the rooftops of the attic.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: She studies the unopened letter and knocks on Mr. Bennet's study door, handing it over. Once alone, Mr. Bennet leaves it on his desk. The housekeeper goes to the garden, while Jane and Lizzie pick fruit. Lizzie quickly leaves with Jane following, searching for their father. They find him in the trees and rush over. Lizzie sits with the letter, later appearing sad in Jane's room. Mr. Darcy appears determined. Lizzie, with a heavy heart, enters her father's study, where they listen to Mrs. Bennet's chatter. A carriage arrives at a grand building; Lydia, in a wedding dress, joins Mr. Wickham, with Mr. Darcy present, at the altar. The Bennets greet Mr. and Mrs. Wickham’s carriage excitedly, Mrs. Bennet leading them inside. Jane and Lizzie exchange glances and follow with Mary and Kitty. While walking, Mr. Wickham shows off his riding skills. Lydia grins at her sisters, and Lizzie appears thoughtful. Mr. Gardiner finalizes the arrangement. Wickham finds Lizzie reading the letter, and they awkwardly walk together in Longbourn's gardens.
